Comment: Times Opinion columnist Lydia Polgreen says in a conversation with Patrick Healy, the deputy Opinion editor:  >Having spent most of my life living overseas and particularly living in poor countries, in Africa and in Asia, there’s such a mix of admiration, longing and resentment for the United States.  >That experience of dependency, of needing American aid or needing America’s assistance if you’re a NATO country, of kind of living in a global economy that’s dominated by the United States — that has been a source of just extraordinary resentment.  >What I think Donald Trump has done is actually given people permission around the world to give full voice to that anger and resentment at the United States that has always kind of bubbled below the surface.  America has been the “hail fellow well met” on the global stage for a very long time — people are happy to see us, but then also resent our self-satisfaction and our wealth and our military power, but then also depend on it.  Read or listen to the full episode of “The Opinions” [here, for free](https://www.nytimes.com/2025/04/24/opinion/trump-immigration-first-100-days.html?unlocked_article_code=1.CE8.onZL.SqkXGtChxwxA&smid=re-nytopinion), even without a Times subscription.
